DataElementConcept.preferredName: Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events Cerebral Edema
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A standard terminology developed to report adverse events occurring in cancer clinical trials.  Common terminology criteria for adverse events (CTCAE) are used in study adverse event summaries and Investigational New Drug reports to the Food and Drug Administration.  The CTCAE contain a grading scale for each adverse event term representing the severity of the event._Swelling due to an excessive accumulation of fluid in the brain.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A standard terminology developed to report adverse events occurring in cancer clinical trials.  Common terminology criteria for adverse events (CTCAE) are used in study adverse event summaries and Investigational New Drug reports to the Food and Drug Administration.  The CTCAE contain a grading scale for each adverse event term representing the severity of the event.

Concepts.longName: Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events
Concepts.definition: A standard terminology developed to report adverse events occurring in cancer clinical trials.  Common terminology criteria for adverse events (CTCAE) are used in study adverse event summaries and Investigational New Drug reports to the Food and Drug Administration.  The CTCAE contain a grading scale for each adverse event term representing the severity of the event.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A branch of medicine concerned with the development, anatomy, function, and dysfunction of the nervous system.: Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.: Area of greatest concentration, attention, or activity; a central point or locus, especially of an infection.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Swelling due to an excessive accumulation of fluid at a specific anatomic site.: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.
Area of greatest concentration, attention, or activity; a central point or locus, especially of an infection.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

PermissibleValues.value: Diffuse cerebral edema on neuroimaging; decerebrate or decorticate posturing; or cranial nerve VI palsy; or papilledema; or Cushing's triad
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neurology Image Diffuse Cerebral Edema Decerebrate Posture Decorticate Posture 6 Cranial Nerve Palsy Papilledema Or Cushing Triad Disease or Disorder

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neurology Image Diffuse Cerebral Edema Decerebrate Posture Decorticate Posture 6 Cranial Nerve Palsy Papilledema Or Cushing Triad Disease or Disorder
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A branch of medicine concerned with the development, anatomy, function, and dysfunction of the nervous system.: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.: Widely spread; not localized or confined.: Swelling due to an excessive accumulation of fluid in the brain.: A posture characterized body rigidity and by extension of the neck, arms, and legs. It may indicate brain stem damage and may suggest herniation of the brain.: A posture characterized by body rigidity, flexion of the arms over the chest, clenched fists,  and extension of the legs. It may indicate cerebral damage.: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::6: Injury to any of the cranial nerves or their nuclei in the brain resulting in muscle weakness.: Swelling around the optic disc, usually due to increased intracranial pressure or pressure on the optic nerve by a tumor.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: A group of signs that often occurs in response to increased intracranial pressure: hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular breathing.: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Concepts.definition: A branch of medicine concerned with the development, anatomy, function, and dysfunction of the nervous system.
Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.
Widely spread; not localized or confined.
Swelling due to an excessive accumulation of fluid in the brain.
A posture characterized body rigidity and by extension of the neck, arms, and legs. It may indicate brain stem damage and may suggest herniation of the brain.
A posture characterized by body rigidity, flexion of the arms over the chest, clenched fists,  and extension of the legs. It may indicate cerebral damage.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
Injury to any of the cranial nerves or their nuclei in the brain resulting in muscle weakness.
Swelling around the optic disc, usually due to increased intracranial pressure or pressure on the optic nerve by a tumor.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
A group of signs that often occurs in response to increased intracranial pressure: hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular breathing.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

PermissibleValues.value: Clinical concern for cerebral edema / elevated intracranial pressure
